response.answer_text: I am considering the meaning of oil lasting to be the time when oil is no longer technically recoverable. By technical recovery I mean to say that the energy needed to extract and refine 1 barrel of oil will be equal or greater than energy released by the final oil products worth 1 barrel of crude oil. Immaterial of what the cost of oil be, it will be unfeasible at this time. One may still get some amount of oil just for the sake of defense aircrafts, missiles etc by using energy from coal to power the extraction but that will not be possible in industrial scale, in the excess of 100 thousand barrel per day as coal is also finite and it will be meaningless for anyone to use energy from oil instead of energy from coal Now, about the oil in Mid east, the countries in mid east have not disclosed their oil reserves for a long time and have kept the reserves same for over 30 years without discovering any new field despite extracting billions of barrels of oil Lets take the case if KSA(saudi arabia). In 87, it was 170 billion barrels and suddenly became 266 billion barrels in 89 and it is same even today. My calculations is that KSA oil in place in 1970 as per US companies report who were co-owners of ARAMCO back then, was 530 bbl. Of this, the initial recovery percentage was expected to be 30% and hence estimated at 170 billion barrels. However, with EOR techniques it was found that the recovery could be 55–60%. Even if we assume best case 65%, the oil extractable in 1970 will be 330 billion barrels. From 1970 to today 150 Billion barrels have been extracted. So, remaining is 180 billion barrels. At 10.5 million barrels per day, the annual extraction will be 4bbl. So, 45 years is what KSA oil will last. Iranian natural gas and oil are also going yo last 50–55 years. Kuwait oil was likewise estimated to be 48 billion barrels in 2006 by oil intelligence journalists. It has annual production of 1 billion barrels and has by now 37 billion barrels of oil. This will last only 40 years. Iraq produces 2 billion barrels of oil per annum and has reseeves of 100 billion barrels which will last 50 years. Abu dhabi has oil of 50 billion barrels at 1 billion barrels annual production and will last 50 years. The figures are based on 1980 reserves of these countries doubled to reflect the advanced techniques of extraction and subtracted by total amount of oil extracted till date. I have purposely made the figures quite generous as I wanted to have the best case scenario as the data is patchy. The oil discovery is ruled out as entire middle east was scavenged in the 1970s after the 1973 gulf blockade and all the oil fields were discovered completely in all the gulf nations excepting IRAQ as all the gulf nations except iraq had US puppet government (including iran) till I 970s and the American companies were allowed to explore the region. The maximum oil can last is 2070 at current production rate in mid-east. However, internal consumption is raising with population and the oil extraction will peak out and decline, instead of suddenly stopping after running continuously at full production. So, 2050 is the possible peak out time and oil will never recover in mid east after that. Nevertheless it is not possible to state when the technical feasibility will end. This is because the decline will be inverse function in nature approaching 0 at infinity. However, the amount of oil that can be extracted will just decrease rapidly after 2050 approaching zero as time passes. Digressing from the topic,the current oil and gas reserves for the world is enough to last 55 years at current production. If we consider the entire world oil and gas including possible but yet undiscovered shale oil and gas, the world reserves will only double (though shale oil and gas is 200% of conventional oil and gas, about 25% of them have already been discovered and included in current figures. Also, the shale requires energy intensive extraction which reduces the technical feasibility to 35–40%). Considering that world population will be 10 billion by 2070 and the standards of living will rise drastically especially in developing countries like India and China, the situation is going to get worse despite new discoveries. The consumption of oil is expected to double and it is likely to nullify the effect of increasing discovery. The peak oil may be slightly delayed but it will be there mostly by 2070 and even natural gas is likely to peak at the same time. By 2100, one can expect the oil to be barely extractable and almost technically unfeasible. End of oil - Full disclosure: This is a canned answer built after answering this same question in slightly different wording several times. It is updated as needs be. First, last and always, the world will never run out of coal, oil or natural gas. This is not because of some unlimited supply the public is unaware of or some miraculous regeneration previously unknown to science. This is because the energy industry and the world's scientists are continually investigating new and/or improved sources of energy, improved techniques in finding and recovering hydrocarbons and improving the efficiency of all variety of devices that utilize these energy sources. The costs associated with fossil fuels will fluctuate over time just as it has since the Colonel hit that first strike in PA. Meanwhile the costs of non-fossil, renewable sources will continue to drop as technology develops to improve those sources. Eventually, in different locations around the world, at different times, those expenses will flip and future production after that will be solely for non-energy needs that will support higher prices that fuel or electrical generation. One must realize that there are many uses of oil and gas beyond energy already (Insecticides, Ink, Floor Wax, Pens, Upholstery, Clothing, Boats, Sports Car Bodies, Nail Polish, Fishing Lures, etc.) and the need for flight fuel will most likely be the longest lasting energy need. The bottom line is what does it cost to generate and how many are willing/able to pay that expense.

I guess it is still a secret that the US is the #1 oil producer and (arguably) has the #1 reserves and has been for a couple of years. At the current rate of consumption (8 billion barrels/year) and reserves of 250billion, we have about 30 years left of our oil. The world has roughly 70 years of oil at the current rate of consumption. Consumption will increase as the population increases and the standard of living improves, but also more oil will be found to produce. Right now, oil is quite cheap because new technology in the US made shale oil profitable in the mid-2000s. It is almost certain that if supply began to run out, prices would rise, and new technology would be applied to currently too-expensive oil deposits. Then, those new deposits would add to the supply. For example, the US technology (horizontal drilling and fracturing) could probably be applied in many other countries for oil and/or natural gas. Don’t forget that there are vast untapped natural gas supplies in many areas of the world and those can be turned into oil products also, if need be. The US has 2,459 trillion cubic feet (Tcf), or about 80 years worth at the current consumption rate. It is much more likely that we will find better (cleaner, cheaper) sources of energy long before the oil and gas runs out. Next generation nuclear reactors are very promising. At the very least, widespread use of renewable energy will trim the use of oil and gas and extend the life of the known supplies. The first thing, first: - need to define and agree on what your term “run out of oil” means to you, or anybody else out there! One thing is a physical term “out of oil”, which simply means - (1) no more oil production, as all the oil bearing reservoirs (oil carrying rocks/sandstone/shale, …) are empty of oil. Kaput, no more oil! However, there is another thing, or a state of the oil production, whereby (2) oil is ceased to be produced because there are no more buyers, as the oil price became so prohibitive expensive - nobody wants it anymore. At least, not wanted as nearly as much, as it is wanted today. Therefore, I would propose that (1) would NEVER happen, as some time in the future (20 - 30 yrs from now, or whenever) - the another scenario (2) would become the reality of life. The World and life on this Earth would be shifting to another energy sources, as the oil simply will become so expensive. The oil will be (then) produced in much smaller quantities, just for the needs (chemical industry, etc.) of those entities who can swallow the oil price of, say, $600 per barrel of oil (in today’s $$$). And then, when for those reasons the oil production drops so much (say, at 10% of today’s rate of prod.) - oil production could last “forever”. And all that goes for the Middle East oil, or any other oil producing region in the World.

Thanks for the request. There are variables in determining when a resource will ‘run out’ such as daily extraction, financial viability of extraction, processing costs. Something that is dirt cheap to extract and process will be used up faster than something that does not give the same profit margin. Business will then determine whether it makes economical sense to go after resources that do not give their expected profit margin and then play with production to maximize profits. Based on the profitability of the organization and the country, the Middle East may never run out of Oil and Gas as mentioned by other people. Hope this shed some light.

Conventional oil reserves may run out in the course of this century, maybe in 50 years or so. Although there are deposits that cannot be developed economically yet and are therefore not listed as “reserves”. There are for examples Arctic deposits, that will become exploitable in the next decades. Middle Eastern governments generally lie about their oil reserves, so estimates about how much is left vary a lot. On top of that, due to the development of unconventional oil resources - oil shale and oil sands - “peak oil” has been delayed indefinitely.

Oil reserve estimates are only indicative and should not be relied upon too much. New oil fields get discovered every now and then in places you may not expect them to be. Also, I would say, people may move to a different fuel before the oil runs out. It may just be a matter of time before hydrogen becomes safer to use or if another safe and reliable energy source presents itself. As they say, "the stone age did not end because of lack of stone."
